NODE_TEXT:
2. Select the "Advanced -> Advanced Settings..." command via the "terminal bus" connection context menu in order to set the network adapters. In order to ensure fault-free communication via the terminal bus on all nodes (e.g. OS servers, OS clients), the relevant network card must be located in first position as regards the order in which the network services are accessed.

Note

The setting of the connection order is neither possible nor necessary for Windows 10.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# 4.3 Installation

3. Set the settings for the "Internet (TCP/IP)" protocol inside the network connection in accordance with the project specifications.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

37

# Preparation and administration

# 4.3 Installation

1. Ensure that the energy-saving option is switched off in the network card properties.
2. Set the same work group for all PCS 7 stations where you are not using a domain structure.
3. Create the LMHOSTS and HOSTS files for the NETBIOS name resolution and distribute these files to all PCS 7 stations. The "LMHOSTS" file is located in the following file path in Windows: "<Drive>\Windows\system32\drivers\etc\".
4. In the "LMHOSTS" file use the parameter #PRE for each computer name to be entered so that this name is entered into the so-called NETBIOS cache when the computer is booted up. (The cache can be displayed via the command line using the "nbtstat –c" command)

Note

You can find additional information on the setup, management and protection of network structures such as workgroups and domains in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Security Concept PCS 7 & WinCC (Basic)" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/60119725) document. After installation of the operating system, the "public network" network profile is configured by default for the network connections, which is not released for the terminal bus in PCS 7. You can find information on the connection to the terminal bus in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 - PC Configuration" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109749317) manual ("How to set up a work group for connection to the terminal bus" section).

NOTICE

In the case of logical network segmentation using a subnet mask based on the same physical network (shared plant and terminal bus), the "Internet protocol version 6 (TCP/IPv6)" check box must be cleared. IPv6 should not be deactivated using the check box in the properties of the "Internet protocol Version 6 (TCP/IPv6)". Instead, the approach recommended by Microsoft should be used for this: (https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/929852/how-to-disable-ipv6-or-its-components-in-windows)

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Preparation and administration

# 4.3 Installation

Checking the availability of communication partners

Once the network settings for the terminal bus are completed, you can use the SIMATIC Shell tool on each station to check if the required partner stations (ES, OS server, and OS clients) can be seen on the terminal bus. SIMATIC Shell is available as a folder in the workspace of the Windows Explorer.

If there is no required partner station in SIMATIC Shell, it may indicate that the TCP/IP name resolution is poorly set. There are several concepts for a TCP/IP network in this regard, beginning with the editing of the LMHOSTS and HOSTS files and continuing with the use of WINS/DNS servers.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

A1: By selecting the 'Advanced -> Advanced Settings...' command via the 'terminal bus' connection context menu.
A2: Access the 'terminal bus' connection context menu and choose 'Advanced -> Advanced Settings...' to configure the network adapters.
A3: The configuration involves navigating to 'Advanced -> Advanced Settings...' in the terminal bus connection's context menu.
A4: To set network adapters, use the 'Advanced Settings...' option under 'Advanced' in the terminal bus connection context menu.
A5: In the terminal bus connection context menu, select 'Advanced' then 'Advanced Settings...' to adjust network adapter settings.

Q: What is the importance of the network card's position in the order of network services access for the terminal bus?
A1: The relevant network card must be in first position to ensure fault-free communication on all nodes like OS servers and clients.
A2: For seamless terminal bus communication across all nodes, the network card should lead in the network services access order.
A3: Positioning the network card first in the access order is crucial for uninterrupted terminal bus communication.
A4: Fault-free terminal bus communication requires the network card to be prioritized in the network services access sequence.
A5: Ensuring the network card is first in the access order guarantees smooth terminal bus operations on all nodes.

Q: How should the 'LMHOSTS' file be configured for NETBIOS name resolution as per the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Use the parameter #PRE for each computer name in the 'LMHOSTS' file to enter it into the NETBIOS cache at boot.
A2: Include #PRE with each computer name in 'LMHOSTS' to ensure it's loaded into the NETBIOS cache during startup.
A3: Configuring 'LMHOSTS' involves appending #PRE to computer names for automatic NETBIOS cache inclusion.
A4: For effective name resolution, tag each computer name in 'LMHOSTS' with #PRE for boot-time cache entry.
A5: The #PRE parameter in 'LMHOSTS' facilitates the preloading of computer names into the NETBIOS cache.

NODE_TEXT:
2. Select the "Advanced -> Advanced Settings..." command via the "terminal bus" connection context menu in order to set the network adapters. In order to ensure fault-free communication via the terminal bus on all nodes (e.g. OS servers, OS clients), the relevant network card must be located in first position as regards the order in which the network services are accessed.

Note

The setting of the connection order is neither possible nor necessary for Windows 10.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

37

# Preparation and administration

# 4.3 Installation

1. Ensure that the energy-saving option is switched off in the network card properties.
2. Set the same work group for all PCS 7 stations where you are not using a domain structure.
3. Create the LMHOSTS and HOSTS files for the NETBIOS name resolution and distribute these files to all PCS 7 stations. The "LMHOSTS" file is located in the following file path in Windows: "<Drive>\Windows\system32\drivers\etc\".
4. In the "LMHOSTS" file use the parameter #PRE for each computer name to be entered so that this name is entered into the so-called NETBIOS cache when the computer is booted up. (The cache can be displayed via the command line using the "nbtstat –c" command)

Note

You can find additional information on the setup, management and protection of network structures such as workgroups and domains in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 Security Concept PCS 7 & WinCC (Basic)" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/60119725) document. After installation of the operating system, the "public network" network profile is configured by default for the network connections, which is not released for the terminal bus in PCS 7. You can find information on the connection to the terminal bus in the "SIMATIC Process Control System PCS 7 - PC Configuration" (https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/ww/en/view/109749317) manual ("How to set up a work group for connection to the terminal bus" section).

NOTICE

In the case of logical network segmentation using a subnet mask based on the same physical network (shared plant and terminal bus), the "Internet protocol version 6 (TCP/IPv6)" check box must be cleared. IPv6 should not be deactivated using the check box in the properties of the "Internet protocol Version 6 (TCP/IPv6)". Instead, the approach recommended by Microsoft should be used for this: (https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/929852/how-to-disable-ipv6-or-its-components-in-windows)

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

# Preparation and administration

# 4.3 Installation

Checking the availability of communication partners

Once the network settings for the terminal bus are completed, you can use the SIMATIC Shell tool on each station to check if the required partner stations (ES, OS server, and OS clients) can be seen on the terminal bus. SIMATIC Shell is available as a folder in the workspace of the Windows Explorer.

If there is no required partner station in SIMATIC Shell, it may indicate that the TCP/IP name resolution is poorly set. There are several concepts for a TCP/IP network in this regard, beginning with the editing of the LMHOSTS and HOSTS files and continuing with the use of WINS/DNS servers.

Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)

Configuration Manual, 03/2018, A5E43228900-AA

39

# Preparation and administration

# 4.3 Installation

You can trigger a refresh of the SIMATIC Shell using "Settings ..." in the shortcut menu. Select the network adapter for the terminal bus and click "OK".
Q: What is the recommended approach for deactivating IPv6 in Windows according to the 'Compendium Part A - Configuration Guidelines (V9.0)'?
A1: Follow Microsoft's recommended approach for deactivating IPv6, not just by clearing the 'Internet protocol version 6 (TCP/IPv6)' check box.
A2: Instead of unchecking IPv6 in network properties, adhere to Microsoft's guidelines for proper deactivation.
A3: The guidelines advise against simply disabling IPv6 via its properties and recommend Microsoft's official method.
A4: Proper IPv6 deactivation requires following Microsoft's recommendations, not just toggling the protocol's check box.
A5: To disable IPv6, the guidelines suggest using Microsoft's approach rather than the straightforward check box method.

Q: What actions can be taken if a required partner station is not visible in SIMATIC Shell?
A1: It may indicate poor TCP/IP name resolution, suggesting a review of LMHOSTS and HOSTS files or the use of WINS/DNS servers.
A2: Absence of a partner station could signal TCP/IP name resolution issues, necessitating file edits or server configurations.
A3: If a station is missing, examine TCP/IP name resolution settings, including LMHOSTS, HOSTS, or WINS/DNS servers.
A4: Missing stations in SIMATIC Shell require troubleshooting TCP/IP name resolution through various network concepts.
A5: Addressing invisible partner stations involves assessing and adjusting TCP/IP name resolution mechanisms.
